message.content: The generated code currently stores users and chats in memory, which means that all data will be lost if the server restarts. A better approach would be to use a database to persist this data. This could be a SQL database like PostgreSQL or a NoSQL database like MongoDB, depending on the specific needs of the application.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The test for the login function is failing because it's comparing the user ID from the response with the user ID of the user object created in the test. However, the user ID is generated randomly in the User class, so these IDs will not match. A better approach would be to return the user object from the register function and use this object in the login test. This way, the user ID in the response will match the user ID of the user object.

function_call.name: write_files

message.content: The test for the login function is still failing because the test_register function is being called inside the test_login function, which creates a new user with a different ID each time. Instead of calling the test_register function inside the test_login function, you could create a setup function that creates a user and returns the user data. This setup function can then be called before each test to ensure that the same user is used in all tests.
